However , the applicant was not able to sign the contract and move in , as it was occupied by A.

On DATE ORG ( PERSON podnik ) informed the housing department of LOC local council that the flat had been occupied by A. without any justification since the death of the former occupant and that PERSON was registered as living in his GPE flat , situated in the same house . On DATE the occupant of the flat had been placed in a welfare institution . CARDINAL . At DATE the applicant joined the proceedings and claimed that he had the right to occupy the flat . A. counter - claimed that he was entitled to have the right to occupy the flat transferred to him .

CARDINAL . On DATE new legislation was enacted which started the process of denationalisation of ORG - owned flats . As a result , the flat ceased to be at the disposal of ORG and the latter lost locus standi in the proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the applicant that there had been no consumption of electricity in the flat as of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant unsuccessfully requested PERSON local council to sign a contract with him for the use of the flat .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE I ORG discontinued the proceedings concerning the action brought by ORG and the counter - claim filed by NORP The court noted that in the course of the proceedings the ownership rights in respect of the flat had been transferred ex lege to LOC municipality and that both the latter and PERSON had withdrawn their actions .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE I ORG granted A. ’s application , filed on CARDINAL DATE , concerning his right to occupy the flat . It concluded that ORG had acquired the right to use the flat pursuant to LAW as in force at the relevant time .

CARDINAL . On DATE the DATE newspaper ORG published a full- page article written by a journalist on the applicant ’s case . It was entitled “ Absurd ? Absurd ! ” . The article contained , inter alia , a description of the applicant ’s unsuccessful attempt to enter the flat on DATE and of the verbal exchanges between the applicant , on the one hand , and A. and his wife PERSON , a public prosecutor , on the other . The article stated that the flat allocated to the applicant had been unlawfully occupied by A. and criticised the fact that the applicant had no possibility of using it .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG brought disciplinary proceedings against PERSON on the ground that , during the applicant ’s attempt to enter the flat on CARDINAL DATE , she had behaved in an inappropriate manner . The decision stated that the disciplinary proceedings had been brought on the basis of the article published in GPE on DATE and of the explanations given by the persons involved . PERSON later resigned from her post of public prosecutor .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant addressed an open letter to the Prime Minister . It was entitled “ For How Long ? ” , and its relevant parts read as follows :

CARDINAL . The letter was signed by the applicant and gave his address . It also gave the full name and profession of both DATE copy of it was posted up at several tram and bus stops in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE lodged with ORG ( ORG súd ) a civil action against the applicant to protect their good name and reputation . They later extended their action to GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE a witness confirmed before ORG that , at the relevant time , PERSON was living with his father .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found in favour of A. and H. It ordered the applicant to apologise in writing for damaging the plaintiffs’ honour . The applicant was further ordered to pay CARDINAL NORP korunas ( SKK ) to each of the plaintiffs for non - pecuniary damage , to reimburse their lawyer ’s fees and to pay the court fees . PERSON was ordered to publish an apology , pay another SKK CARDINAL,CARDINAL to each of the plaintiffs and reimburse their legal costs .

CARDINAL . ORG noted that proceedings were pending before the Bratislava I ORG which concerned ORG ’s claim for the flat in issue to be vacated and ORG ’s counter - claim . ORG held that the proceedings before ORG raised difficult questions of fact and law . It further held that the applicant had not , so far , acquired the right to occupy the flat and noted that , according to a document issued by the housing department of LOC local council on DATE , ORG was under no obligation to vacate the flat until he obtained alternative accommodation .

CARDINAL . In ORG view , the opinions of the applicant and of a journalist which had been published in GPE on DATE and CARDINAL DATE had not been substantiated . The court considered that the applicant had also interfered with the plaintiffs’ right to protection of their personality by displaying his open letter of CARDINAL DATE in public places or , as the case may be , allowing it to be published . The court held that the letter contained tendentious , distorted and unsubstantiated information which had damaged the plaintiffs’ personal integrity .

CARDINAL . ORG found that the damage had affected PERSON ’s health , that , following the publication of the article of CARDINAL DATE , disciplinary proceedings had been brought against her and that , for the same reason , a loan had not been granted to A. , who was a businessman . The family life of the claimants and of H. ’s children had also been affected .

CARDINAL . Both the applicant and PERSON appealed . The applicant claimed , with reference to the documents included in the case file , that the information contained in his open letter of CARDINAL DATE was true . In particular , he argued that , under the relevant law , A. had no right to occupy the flat in question . He also offered proof that , at the relevant time , PERSON had had a permanent address with his parents and that his wife had had the right to occupy another flat .

CARDINAL . The applicant also pointed out that he could not have the contract for the use of the flat signed as the flat had been illegally occupied by A. He therefore maintained that his conclusion that ORG had prevented him from moving into the flat was correct . Finally , the applicant alleged that , in any event , the interference in question had not had any defamatory effect within the meaning of LAW and that ORG had not indicated any relevant damage or circumstance within the meaning of LAW on which its conclusion had been based .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Najvyšší súd ) dismissed the appeal . It considered that the evidence heard by ORG showed that the information contained in the article of CARDINAL DATE , in the applicant ’s opinion published in GPE on DATE and in the applicant ’s open letter displayed in public places did not correspond to reality and was objectively capable of affecting the plaintiffs’ personality rights .

CARDINAL . ORG recalled that , after the allocation of the flat to the applicant , the relevant authorities had not signed a contract for its use with him as required by the law then in force and that the applicant had not requested that such a contract be signed . ORG therefore considered that the applicant ’s allegation that A. had occupied the flat in question unlawfully and that he had shamefully benefited from the fact that his permanent address was the same as that of the flat in question had been tendentious and misleading as the proceedings concerning the right to occupy the flat in issue were still pending before the Bratislava I ORG .

CARDINAL . In ORG view , the disclosure , in both the open letter and the opinion of DATE , of ORG ’s name and of the fact that she was a public prosecutor had grossly interfered with her right to protection of her personality . It concluded that the way in which the applicant had attempted to resolve his housing problem was inappropriate as he had had other lawful means of seeking redress .

CARDINAL . In the judgment , ORG referred to the profession of the plaintiffs and found that the compensation the applicant had been ordered to pay was appropriate and corresponded to the non - pecuniary damage DATE had suffered . The applicant was ordered to reimburse to the plaintiffs the cost of the proceedings . The judgment was served on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a petition with ORG ( Ústavný súd ) . He alleged a violation of his constitutional rights , including freedom of expression , in the proceedings leading to ORG judgment of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the petition on the ground that it lacked jurisdiction to review or quash the ordinary courts’ decisions and to award compensation to the applicant .
CARDINAL . Subsequently a bailiff started to enforce payment of the sums due by the applicant by attaching CARDINAL of his salary .
CARDINAL . NORP The right to protection of a person ’s dignity , honour , reputation and good name is guaranteed by LAW seq . of LAW .

CARDINAL . Under LAW , any natural person has the right to protection of his or her personality , in particular of his or her life and health , civil and human dignity , privacy , name and personal characteristics .

CARDINAL . According to LAW any natural person has the right to request that unjustified interference with his or her personality rights be stopped and that the consequences of such interference be eliminated , and to obtain just satisfaction .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that , in cases where satisfaction obtained under LAW is insufficient , in particular because a person ’s dignity and position in society have been considerably diminished , the person affected is entitled to compensation in respect of non - pecuniary damage .

CARDINAL . Under LAW , the amount of compensation to be paid LAW CARDINAL § CARDINAL is fixed by the courts after considering the severity of the damage and the circumstances in which the person ’s right was violated .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW , as in force up until DATE , provides that the right to use a flat after the death of the occupant shall be transferred to persons who , inter alia , have lived in a common household with the person entitled to use it for DATE before his or her death , provided that they have no flat of their own .
